normalised: Someone asked me recently why I always donate rupee five hundred to the temple near my house every month, and why I also give rupees two hundred to the old lady who sits outside the station. It's a fair question, and the answer isn't as simple as "being charitable."

See, my dad, he was a government employee, a clerk in a small office in Lucknow. He never earned a lot, maybe rupee fifteen thousand a month back then, in the early two thousands. But every single month, without fail, he would donate rupees one hundred to the local orphanage. Rupees one hundred doesn't seem like a lot now, but back then, it was a significant chunk of his salary. I remember my mother used to complain sometimes – "We have bills to pay, Suresh! The electricity bill is already rupee eight hundred this month!"

unnormalised: Someone asked me recently why I always donate ₹500 to the temple near my house every month, and why I also give Rs. 200 to the old lady who sits outside the station. It's a fair question, and the answer isn't as simple as "being charitable."
normalised: He would always tell her, "Lakshmi, even if we give just a little, it makes a difference. Those children need it more than we need an extra saree or fancy mithai.” And he was right. He wasn’t giving crores, or even lakhs, but that rupees one hundred ensured that some child got a slightly better meal that day.

normalised: One year, during Diwali, there was a flood in our neighbourhood. We lost almost everything. My dad, instead of buying new clothes for us (as was tradition) took the rupee two thousand he had saved up to buy crackers and sweets for Diwali and donated rupees one thousand five hundred to the flood relief fund. My mom was furious. But later that evening, we found a group of volunteers giving out hot meals and blankets in our locality. The smile on his face at that moment, witnessing the direct impact of his small contribution, is something I'll never forget.

normalised: That's why I donate rupees five hundred to the temple now. It’s not about religious merit. It’s about contributing to the langar they run, feeding hundreds of people daily. That money, plus the other donations they receive, means that someone who can’t afford a meal gets one. And that rupees two hundred I give to the old lady? She uses it to buy medicine and chai. I know it's not much, but hopefully, it eases her burden a little.
